description: From Middle English pouten, probably from Scandinavian (compare Norwegian pute (“pillow, cushion”), dial. Swedish puta (“to be puffed out”), Danish pude (“pillow, cushion”)), from Proto-Germanic *pūto (“swollen”) (compare English eelpout, Dutch puit, Low German puddig (“inflated”)), from Proto-Indo-European *bu- (“to swell”) (compare Sanskrit बुद्बुद (budbuda, “bubble”)).

examples: With a pout, Natasha counted the drops, and her eyelashes kept time.

entries.meaning: A fit of sulking or sullenness.

verbs.description: pout (third-person singular simple present pouts, present participle pouting, simple past and past participle pouted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To thrust itself outward; to be prominent.
(intransitive) To be or pretend to be ill-tempered; to sulk.

examples: "Don't you love me any more?" she pouted.

description: From Middle English *poute, from Old English *pūte as in ǣlepūta, ǣlepūte (“eelpout”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bew- (“to swell”). Related to pout (“to push one's lip out”).

entries.meaning: (rare) Any of various fishes such as the hornpout (Ameiurus nebulosus, the brown bullhead), the pouting (Trisopterus luscus) and the eelpouts (Zoarcidae).

verbs.description: pout (third-person singular simple present pouts, present participle pouting, simple past and past participle pouted)
